candidates.title: feat(repo): Added api optimizations and improvements

- [x] added pagination validation with limits
- [x] added pagination flattened structure
- [x] moved to very ergonomic traits with defaults - reduced boiler-plate code
- [x] updated db structure references (table columns)

- [x] added branas as a codeowner
- [x] added mock endpoint for getting blocks

candidates.title: feat(repo): Add pointers inside the StreamResponse
candidates.body:
This PR introduces a fundamental change in how we stream data in our architecture by implementing Record Pointers plus a lot of improvements and reduce of complexity.

## Core Changes
- Introduced Record Pointers to show pointer from the database items in the final stream data 
- Remove overhead over packet creation
- Move historical streaming method to core stream crate
- Remove unnecessary overhead on types and conversions between them
- Move RecordEntity dependent operations to FuelStreams and FuelStores
- Centralize packets conversions from subjects in the domain packets files and reuse in the tests
- Modified store operations:
  - `insert_record` now accepts a database item
  - Store operations now convert packets to database items before insertion

## Additional Changes
- Updated test infrastructure to support the new pointer-based approach
- Enhanced namespace handling across record operations
- Improved consumer service to work with the new pointer system

Example of the new StreamResponse with RecordPointer:

```json
{
    "version": "v1",
    "type": "input",
    "subject": "inputs.coin.height.1234.tx.0x123...index.2",
    "pointer": {
        "block_height": 1234,
        "tx_index": 5,
        "input_index": 2,
        "output_index": null,
        "receipt_index": null
    },
    "payload": {
        ...
    }
}
```

This architectural change provides better type safety and a more efficient way to handle database records while reducing memory overhead in our data systems.

- [x] Fixed multiple issues to fuel-webserver crate in middleware, metrics, routers, extractors
- [x] Fixed all metrics across all services
- [x] added new endpoint for adding api keys
- [x] added fuel-db-utils for generating api keys on db load
- [x] added simple request limiter (next release will add redis for atomicity)
- [x] extended docker-compose file with infra for local running of telemetry

- [x] added prometheus and grafana official helm charts to cluster

feat(repo): Added web-utils crate and added telemetry to all svc
candidates.body:
This PR:
- creates a new web-utils crate which is dynamic and easy to inject in every single microservice
- the latter combines metrics (telemetry), shutdowns, routes, middlewares and exposes them as for direct use
- the crate is then used throughout in all our services exposing metrics and healthchecks
- shutdown handlers are also everywhere now added
- Makefile and scripts updated
- repetitive code is removed

candidates.title: feat(webserver): Add TLS configuration for WebServer
build(repo): Add TLS configuration for WebServer
feat(repo): Merge nats s3 hybrid publishing into main
feat: Adjusts to release S3 + WebServer
fix(repo): Solving publisher slowness
candidates.body:
> [!WARNING]
> THIS PR IS A TEMPORARILY SOLUTION, IT WILL NOT BE MERGED ON MAIN FOR NOW

candidates.title: refactor(repo): Improve DevOps stack and configuration
feat(publisher): Extend NATS publishing by storing payloads in S3
candidates.body:
This PR enhances our current Publisher strategy by publishing 
the payloads in S3 and storing the path pointer in NATS

Closes DS-125

candidates.title: fix(publisher): Simplify and test BlocksStream for old and new blocks
candidates.body:
BlocksStream now streams old blocks until reaching the latest chain height,
after which it subscribes to new blocks from the fuel-core importer.

This refactor removes the need for the UnpublishedBlocks abstraction, which
previously managed batches of blocks but caused contention issues, starving
fuel-core of its synchronization capacity.

By simplifying the block-handling logic, this fix improves performance, reduces
complexity, and ensures fuel-core can sync effectively.

candidates.title: feat(repo): Updated crates and npm packages
feat(repo): Fixed nats-url exposure and duplication
candidates.body:
The idea of this PR is to achieve consistency of all used nats urls and also mask them to the end-user. This is on the one hand to ensure security by not disclosing an open nats url,  on the other to help the user not having to bother about the url in general, but rather define the fuel-network he cares about. Sam thing has been done on the ts-sdk and it results in a clean design.
Also, we avoid a lot of hardcoded values this way and values re-defined over and over again in the monorepo.

candidates.title: fix(publisher): Resolve block publication race conditions and synchronization issues
candidates.body:
## Problem
The current blocks stream publishing mechanism suffers from two critical synchronization challenges:

1. **Receipt Population Failure**: Blocks were not being populated with receipts due to the OffchainDB being out of sync with the OnChainDB.

2. **Block Synchronization Bottleneck**: The existing block import mechanism used a blocking synchronization approach that:
   - Introduced significant latency during block synchronization
   - Risked missing blocks during the import process
   - Blocked the block subscription until all historical blocks were processed

## Solution
This commit introduces the `UnpublishedBlocks` abstraction to resolve these issues:

- Implements a flexible, non-blocking block synchronization strategy
- Ensures blocks are published in sequence based on their heights
- Allows immediate block subscription while synchronizing historical blocks
- Adds a mechanism to wait for OffchainDB to catch up before publishing streams

### Future Improvements
As a potential optimization, when streams are separated into different processes, we can further refine the synchronization strategy to avoid waiting for OffchainDB sync for certain stream types.

References: DS-124

candidates.title: fix(core): Adjust type for better TS SDK compatibility
feat(repo): Introduce FuelStreams Types
candidates.body:
Currently, `fuel-core` types are directly exposed to users for streaming. However, this approach has several drawbacks:

1. The serialized structures are tailored for Rust, making them difficult to integrate with existing SDKs.
2. The unstructured serialized output complicates compatibility efforts.
3. Exposing `fuel-core` types could mislead users into assuming related APIs, which require a configured environment, are usable directly with streams.

This PR addresses these issues by introducing `FuelStreams` types, designed as aggregation types optimized for broad use cases. These types are derived from the GraphQL interface used in frontend projects, ensuring a structured and user-friendly format.

Moving forward, we will expand these types to include additional fields based on user needs, making them more versatile and compatible across different integrations.

Closes DS-113

_Subtasks:_
Closes DS-114, DS-115, DS-116, DS-117, DS-118
